lines.text: I don't know who you are or where you come from, but if that's all you have to say, then shove off!
I could tell you where to go and you wouldn't need a map.
Tyler, I could tell you where to go and you would not need no map to get there.
I'm warning you, Tommy! You just better not start treating me like a girl!
If you did what you were supposed to, I wouldn't have to keep telling you, now would I?
Sure you would... just to keep in practice.
Once you get a hold on something you never let go. It's enough to drive a body wild.
Well it wouldn't be any long drive for the likes of you.
I take no particular pride in it, but after four wives, I consider myself in a position to know something about boredom.
I'm Tommy Tyler. This *mouth* here is my daughter Spring.
Where do you usually sail, Mr Tyler?
Close to the wind.
Too close, if you ask me.
Nobody asked you.
You'd think with my brains and her mouth we'd be better off than we are.
Your man here's been good enough to supply me with a few odds and ends for the fish I sent over this morning.
The price of fish seems to have gone up.
What do I do with these rags?
Those aren't rags. They're my clothes.
Sleeping in pajamas is something people do without even thinking about it. That's all there is to it. People sleep in pajamas.
I don't.

I ain't been much of a father to you have I? The day you were born I said to myself, here's one for freedom. Here's one they won't get. The night you were launched I reckon I was the happiest guy alive. I couldn't stop wondering what the finest thing I could do for you was. And then I knew... or I thought I knew. Well that 'fine thing' is the life you have now. Only now I'm beginning to wonder if it was the right thing after all. Fathers don't usually figure on their little girls growing up.
Isn't anybody going to tell me what's going on?
Not now. You'll find out soon enough.
That's what I'm afraid of.
Where's Tommy?
He caught the smallpox... and died.
Buried me at sea, did you?
You don't have to look like that, it was a decent funeral.
Thought you was dead.
Didn't like the climate where they sent me so I came back.
[after Ashton is knocked almost unconscious by Sellers]
You just lost your first case, son.
[referring to the copy of Les Miserables Ashton is reading]
You've read it?
Uh-huh, a long time ago. Why do you seem so surprised? I'm not ignorant!
Tommy taught me how to read and write... and how to add and subtract, too. Never did teach me how to multiply and divide. He said that would come naturally.
I didn't care much for learning arithmetic, but Tommy made me. He said education is one of the penalties that go with civilization.
[Prayer before lunch]
As we fare, may others fare. Amen.
I ain't much thought about it.
*Haven't*, not *ain't*.
It means the same thing.
A shoe means the same thing as a boot, but a boot's what you're gonna get in a minute.
Seems to me you're always doing things without thinking, Ashton - wearing pajamas... kissing...
Hasn't anybody ever kissed you?
You did. Nobody else would dare.
You don't catch me painting myself up, do you? Wearing all kinds of hooks and straps and pumping perfume all over me enough to make a pig sick of the smell.
That's not all there is to being a girl.
Well it's enough to turn *me* against it.
I'm me, Ashton. That's all I ever intend to be.
I told you he'd be here. If he hadn't been, I'd of lost all faith in crooks.
Think you can get along with Ashton without me for a while?
I'll work at it.

I got a safe deposit box in Tampa with four thousand one hundred and sixty-seven dollars and twenty-two cents. Now if it develops today I ain't as smart as I think I am, see that she gets into some girls' school. A strict one.
You still angry with me?
Nope. I get over things fast; especially people and other diseases.
You don't think much of people, do you?
I don't know many of them. But if the ones I don't know are like the ones I know, then I don't want to know the ones I don't know.
I doubt he's having a very good time over there.
You don't know him. When he's having the worst time, that's when he's having the best.
My mother raised me to believe the man with the gun is the man who does the talking.
I admire a man who remembers his mother.
What are you thinking so hard about?
You really want to know?
You tell me what it is, and I'll tell you if I want to know.
Will you do me a big favor Spring?
What?
Stop calling me Ashton.
What am I supposed to call you?
Everybody else calls me Bill.
Alright, I'll call you William.

[chagrined]
Thank you. Goodnight Spring.
Goodnight Ashton.

I ain't gonna ask you why you weren't here to get supper last night. And I ain't gonna ask you why you weren't here to get breakfast this morning. I ain't even gonna ask you why you left the Sarah all alone without a soul on board. And I got other things in mind I ain't gonna ask you about.
I want to talk to Ashton.
Are you going to shoot him?
Should I?
He didn't do anything but keep me warm.
That's what God made fire for.
I don't know what you're thinking, but I can assure you...
You don't have to assure me of nothing. I know Springer.
When you kissed me before... well, I really didn't mind it all that much. So... before you go, will you do it again?
Did you mean it when you said I'm not the worst looking thing you ever saw?
I think you're beautiful.
You've become pretty fond of Ashton, haven't you?
[nods]
Do you love him?
[nods]
If he asks you to go with him and marry him... would you?
You think he will, Tommy?
Yep. Yep, I think he will.
You wouldn't hate me then if I left you and married Ashton?
I wouldn't take it kindly if you deprived me of grandchildren!
When you get home, I guess you'll start right in sending people off to prison?
I'm not that kind of lawyer.
I didn't know there was but one kind. You mean there are good ones, too?
You brush your teeth, you hear me? And take a bath once in a while. No Philadelphia lawyer wants his wife smelling like a wharf rat.
